comment_text.mn73:1.1: The final episode in the Vacchagotta trilogy sees our hero rise above his useless metaphysical quandaries and seek a better way to live. The Buddha’s patience is rewarded as Vacchagotta finally achieves his goal.
comment_text.mn73:4.1: Elsewhere (eg. MN 9:4.1) a distinction is drawn between greed, hate, and delusion as the root of the unskillful, while the ten kinds of action are the unskillful (and the same applies to the skillful).
comment_text.mn73:7.2: Two devas mentally ask Mahāvīra a similar question at Bhagavatisūtra 4.5.59; the answer was seven hundred.
comment_text.mn73:9.2: Devoted layfolk would regularly keep the five precepts, which forbid sexual misconduct, and undertake the eight precepts, including celibacy, on the sabbath. However it seems that then, as today, there is a less formalized class of layfolk who would undertake the eight precepts continuously. White-robed, celibate layfolk are mentioned in DN 29:12.11, where they are a property of a fully-developed and prosperous religion. Celibate laypeople are also referred to at AN 5.180 and AN 10.75:2.2. Such layfolk have the potential to realize non-return, since that requires the complete letting go of all forms of desire.
comment_text.mn73:28.7: Vacchagotta’s attainment is also confirmed in his verse at Thag 1.112.

root_text.mn73:2.1: Atha kho vacchagotto paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodi.
root_text.mn73:2.2: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho vacchagotto paribbājako bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn73:3.2: Sādhu me bhavaṁ gotamo saṅkhittena kusalākusalaṁ desetū”ti.
root_text.mn73:3.3: “Saṅkhittenapi kho te ahaṁ, vaccha, kusalākusalaṁ deseyyaṁ, vitthārenapi kho te ahaṁ, vaccha, kusalākusalaṁ deseyyaṁ;
root_text.mn73:3.4: api ca te ahaṁ, vaccha, saṅkhittena kusalākusalaṁ desessāmi.
root_text.mn73:3.5: Taṁ suṇāhi, sādhukaṁ manasi karohi, bhāsissāmī”ti.
root_text.mn73:3.6: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho vacchagotto paribbājako bhagavato paccassosi.

root_text.mn73:6.1: Yato kho, vaccha, bhikkhuno taṇhā pahīnā hoti ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṁ anuppādadhammā, so hoti bhikkhu arahaṁ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṁyojano sammadaññāvimutto”ti.
root_text.mn73:7.2: Atthi pana te bhoto gotamassa ekabhikkhupi sāvako yo āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī”ti?
root_text.mn73:7.3: “Na kho, vaccha, ekaṁyeva sataṁ na dve satāni na tīṇi satāni na cattāri satāni na pañca satāni, atha kho bhiyyova ye bhikkhū mama sāvakā āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī”ti.
root_text.mn73:8.2: Atthi pana bhoto gotamassa ekā bhikkhunīpi sāvikā yā āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī”ti?
root_text.mn73:8.3: “Na kho, vaccha, ekaṁyeva sataṁ na dve satāni na tīṇi satāni na cattāri satāni na pañca satāni, atha kho bhiyyova yā bhikkhuniyo mama sāvikā āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī”ti.
root_text.mn73:9.1: “Tiṭṭhatu bhavaṁ gotamo, tiṭṭhantu bhikkhū, tiṭṭhantu bhikkhuniyo.
root_text.mn73:9.2: Atthi pana bhoto gotamassa ekupāsakopi sāvako gihī odātavasano brahmacārī yo pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātiko tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā”ti?
root_text.mn73:9.3: “Na kho, vaccha, ekaṁyeva sataṁ na dve satāni na tīṇi satāni na cattāri satāni na pañca satāni, atha kho bhiyyova ye upāsakā mama sāvakā gihī odātavasanā brahmacārino pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātikā tattha parinibbāyino anāvattidhammā tasmā lokā”ti.
root_text.mn73:10.1: “Tiṭṭhatu bhavaṁ gotamo, tiṭṭhantu bhikkhū, tiṭṭhantu bhikkhuniyo, tiṭṭhantu upāsakā gihī odātavasanā brahmacārino.
root_text.mn73:10.2: Atthi pana bhoto gotamassa ekupāsakopi sāvako gihī odātavasano kāmabhogī sāsanakaro ovādappaṭikaro yo tiṇṇavicikiccho vigatakathaṅkatho vesārajjappatto aparappaccayo satthusāsane viharatī”ti?
root_text.mn73:10.3: “Na kho, vaccha, ekaṁyeva sataṁ na dve satāni na tīṇi satāni na cattāri satāni na pañca satāni, atha kho bhiyyova ye upāsakā mama sāvakā gihī odātavasanā kāmabhogino sāsanakarā ovādappaṭikarā tiṇṇavicikicchā vigatakathaṅkathā vesārajjappattā aparappaccayā satthusāsane viharantī”ti.

root_text.mn73:13.1: “Sace hi, bho gotama, imaṁ dhammaṁ bhavaṁyeva gotamo ārādhako abhavissa, no ca kho bhikkhū ārādhakā abhavissaṁsu;

root_text.mn73:16.1: “Yo kho, vaccha, aññatitthiyapubbo imasmiṁ dhammavinaye ākaṅkhati pabbajjaṁ, ākaṅkhati upasampadaṁ, so cattāro māse parivasati. Catunnaṁ māsānaṁ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājenti upasampādenti bhikkhubhāvāya;
root_text.mn73:16.3: “Sace, bhante, aññatitthiyapubbā imasmiṁ dhammavinaye ākaṅkhantā pabbajjaṁ, ākaṅkhantā upasampadaṁ cattāro māse parivasanti, catunnaṁ māsānaṁ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājenti upasampādenti bhikkhubhāvāya; ahaṁ cattāri vassāni parivasissāmi. Catunnaṁ vassānaṁ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājentu upasampādentu bhikkhubhāvāyā”ti.
root_text.mn73:16.4: Alattha kho vacchagotto paribbājako bhagavato santike pabbajjaṁ alattha upasampadaṁ.
root_text.mn73:17.1: Acirūpasampanno kho panāyasmā vacchagotto addhamāsūpasampanno yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā vacchagotto bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn73:17.2: “yāvatakaṁ, bhante, sekhena ñāṇena sekhāya vijjāya pattabbaṁ, anuppattaṁ taṁ mayā;
root_text.mn73:17.3: uttari ca me bhagavā dhammaṁ desetū”ti.
root_text.mn73:18.1: “Tena hi tvaṁ, vaccha, dve dhamme uttari bhāvehi—samathañca vipassanañca.
root_text.mn73:18.2: Ime kho te, vaccha, dve dhammā uttari bhāvitā—samatho ca vipassanā ca—anekadhātupaṭivedhāya saṁvattissanti.
root_text.mn73:19.2: ‘anekavihitaṁ iddhividhaṁ paccanubhaveyyaṁ—ekopi hutvā bahudhā assaṁ, bahudhāpi hutvā eko assaṁ; āvibhāvaṁ, tirobhāvaṁ; tirokuṭṭaṁ tiropākāraṁ tiropabbataṁ asajjamāno gaccheyyaṁ, seyyathāpi ākāse; pathaviyāpi ummujjanimujjaṁ kareyyaṁ, seyyathāpi udake; udakepi abhijjamāne gaccheyyaṁ, seyyathāpi pathaviyaṁ; ākāsepi pallaṅkena kameyyaṁ, seyyathāpi pakkhī sakuṇo; imepi candimasūriye evaṁmahiddhike evaṁmahānubhāve pāṇinā parimaseyyaṁ, parimajjeyyaṁ; yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṁ vatteyyan’ti,

root_text.mn73:22.2: ‘anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussareyyaṁ, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi; anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe—amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapannoti; iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussareyyan’ti,

root_text.mn73:23.2: ‘dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passeyyaṁ cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajāneyyaṁ—ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṁ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapannā; ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṁ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannāti; iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passeyyaṁ cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajāneyyan’ti,
root_text.mn73:23.3: tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṁ pāpuṇissasi, sati satiāyatane.
root_text.mn73:24.2: ‘āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyan’ti,
root_text.mn73:24.3: tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṁ pāpuṇissasi, sati satiāyatane”ti.
root_text.mn73:25.1: Atha kho āyasmā vacchagotto bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā pakkāmi.
root_text.mn73:26.1: Atha kho āyasmā vacchagotto eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
root_text.mn73:26.2: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
root_text.mn73:26.3: Aññataro kho panāyasmā vacchagotto arahataṁ ahosi.
root_text.mn73:27.1: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā bhikkhū bhagavantaṁ dassanāya gacchanti.
root_text.mn73:27.2: Addasā kho āyasmā vacchagotto te bhikkhū dūratova āgacchante.
root_text.mn73:27.3: Disvāna yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te bhikkhū etadavoca:
root_text.mn73:27.6: “Tenahāyasmanto mama vacanena bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatha, evañca vadetha:
root_text.mn73:27.7: ‘vacchagotto, bhante, bhikkhu bhagavato pāde sirasā vandati, evañca vadeti—
root_text.mn73:27.8: pariciṇṇo me bhagavā, pariciṇṇo me sugato’”ti.
root_text.mn73:28.1: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato vacchagottassa paccassosuṁ.
root_text.mn73:28.2: Atha kho te bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Ekamantaṁ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.mn73:28.3: “āyasmā, bhante, vacchagotto bhagavato pāde sirasā vandati, evañca vadeti:
root_text.mn73:28.5: “Pubbeva me, bhikkhave, vacchagotto bhikkhu cetasā ceto paricca vidito:
root_text.mn73:28.10: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.

translation_text.mn73:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
translation_text.mn73:2.1: Then the wanderer Vacchagotta went up to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.mn73:2.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn73:3.1: “For a long time I have had discussions with the worthy Gotama.
translation_text.mn73:3.2: Please teach me in brief what is skillful and what is unskillful.”
translation_text.mn73:3.3: “Vaccha, I can teach you what is skillful and what is unskillful in brief or in detail.
translation_text.mn73:3.4: Still, let me do so in brief.
translation_text.mn73:3.5: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn73:4.2: Hate is unskillful, love is skillful.
translation_text.mn73:4.3: Delusion is unskillful, understanding is skillful.
translation_text.mn73:4.4: So there are these three unskillful things and three that are skillful.
translation_text.mn73:5.1: Killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct; speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; covetousness, ill will, and wrong view: these things are unskillful.
translation_text.mn73:5.2: Refraining from killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct; refraining from speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; contentment, kind-heartedness, and right view: these things are skillful.
translation_text.mn73:5.11: So there are these ten unskillful things and ten that are skillful.
translation_text.mn73:6.1: When a mendicant has given up craving so it is cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future, that mendicant is perfected. They’ve ended the defilements, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and are rightly freed through enlightenment.”
translation_text.mn73:7.2: is there even a single monk disciple of the worthy Gotama who has realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and lives having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements?”
translation_text.mn73:7.3: “There are not just one hundred such monks who are my disciples, Vaccha, or two or three or four or five hundred, but many more than that.”
translation_text.mn73:8.1: “Leaving aside the worthy Gotama and the monks,
translation_text.mn73:8.2: is there even a single nun disciple of the worthy Gotama who has realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and lives having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements?”
translation_text.mn73:8.3: “There are not just one hundred such nuns who are my disciples, Vaccha, or two or three or four or five hundred, but many more than that.”
translation_text.mn73:9.1: “Leaving aside the worthy Gotama, the monks, and the nuns,
translation_text.mn73:9.2: is there even a single layman disciple of Mister Gotama—white-clothed and chaste—who, with the ending of the five lower fetters, is reborn spontaneously, to be extinguished there, not liable to return from that world?”
translation_text.mn73:9.3: “There are not just one hundred such chaste laymen who are my disciples, Vaccha, or two or three or four or five hundred, but many more than that.”
translation_text.mn73:10.1: “Leaving aside Mister Gotama, the monks, the nuns, and the chaste laymen,
translation_text.mn73:10.2: is there even a single layman disciple of the worthy Gotama—white-clothed, enjoying sensual pleasures, following instructions, and responding to advice—who has gone beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, and lives self-assured and independent of others regarding the Teacher’s instruction?”
translation_text.mn73:10.3: “There are not just one hundred such laymen enjoying sensual pleasures who are my disciples, Vaccha, or two or three or four or five hundred, but many more than that.”
translation_text.mn73:11.1: “Leaving aside Mister Gotama, the monks, the nuns, the chaste laymen, and the laymen enjoying sensual pleasures,
translation_text.mn73:11.2: is there even a single laywoman disciple of Mister Gotama—white-clothed and chaste—who, with the ending of the five lower fetters, is reborn spontaneously, to be extinguished there, not liable to return from that world?”
translation_text.mn73:11.3: “There are not just one hundred such chaste laywomen who are my disciples, Vaccha, or two or three or four or five hundred, but many more than that.”
translation_text.mn73:12.1: “Leaving aside Mister Gotama, the monks, the nuns, the chaste laymen, the laymen enjoying sensual pleasures, and the chaste laywomen,
translation_text.mn73:12.2: is there even a single laywoman disciple of the worthy Gotama—white-clothed, enjoying sensual pleasures, following instructions, and responding to advice—who has gone beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, and lives self-assured and independent of others regarding the Teacher’s instruction?”
translation_text.mn73:12.3: “There are not just one hundred such laywomen enjoying sensual pleasures who are my disciples, Vaccha, or two or three or four or five hundred, but many more than that.”
translation_text.mn73:13.1: “If the worthy Gotama was the only one to succeed in this teaching, not any monks,
translation_text.mn73:13.2: then this spiritual path would be incomplete in that respect.
translation_text.mn73:13.3: But because both the worthy Gotama and monks have succeeded in this teaching,
translation_text.mn73:13.4: this spiritual path is complete in that respect.
translation_text.mn73:13.5: If the worthy Gotama and the monks were the only ones to succeed in this teaching, not any nuns …
translation_text.mn73:13.22: then this spiritual path would be incomplete in that respect.
translation_text.mn73:13.23: But because Mister Gotama, monks, nuns, chaste laymen, laymen enjoying sensual pleasures, chaste laywomen, and laywomen enjoying sensual pleasures have all succeeded in this teaching,
translation_text.mn73:13.24: this spiritual path is complete in that respect.
translation_text.mn73:14.1: Just as the Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines towards the ocean, and keeps pressing into the ocean, in the same way Mister Gotama’s assembly—with both laypeople and renunciates—slants, slopes, and inclines towards extinguishment, and keeps pressing upon extinguishment.
translation_text.mn73:15.2: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn73:15.3: May I receive the going forth, the ordination in the worthy Gotama’s presence?”
translation_text.mn73:16.1: “Vaccha, if someone formerly ordained in another sect wishes to take the going forth, the ordination in this teaching and training, they must spend four months on probation. When four months have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, they’ll give the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.
translation_text.mn73:16.2: However, I recognize individual differences in this matter.”
translation_text.mn73:16.3: “Sir, if four months probation are required in such a case, I’ll spend four years on probation. When four years have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, let them give me the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.”
translation_text.mn73:16.4: And the wanderer Vaccha received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.
translation_text.mn73:17.1: Not long after his ordination, a fortnight later, Venerable Vacchagotta went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
translation_text.mn73:17.2: “Sir, I’ve reached as far as possible with the knowledge and understanding of a trainee.
translation_text.mn73:18.1: “Well then, Vaccha, further develop two things: serenity and discernment.
translation_text.mn73:18.2: When you have further developed these two things, they’ll lead to the penetration of many elements.
translation_text.mn73:19.1: As far as you want, you will be capable of realizing these things, since each and every one is within range:
translation_text.mn73:19.2: ‘May I wield the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying myself and becoming one again; materializing and dematerializing; going unobstructed through a wall, a rampart, or a mountain as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if it were water; walking on water as if it were earth; flying cross-legged through the sky like a bird; touching and stroking with my hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful; controlling my body as far as the realm of divinity.’
translation_text.mn73:20.1: Whenever you want, you will be capable of realizing these things, since each and every one is within range:
translation_text.mn73:20.2: ‘With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, may I hear both kinds of sounds, human and heavenly, whether near or far.’
translation_text.mn73:21.1: As far as you want, you will be capable of realizing these things, since each and every one is within range:
translation_text.mn73:21.2: ‘May I understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having encompassed them with my mind.
translation_text.mn73:21.3: May I understand mind with greed as “mind with greed”,
translation_text.mn73:21.4: and mind without greed as “mind without greed”;
translation_text.mn73:21.5: mind with hate as “mind with hate”,
translation_text.mn73:21.6: and mind without hate as “mind without hate”;
translation_text.mn73:21.7: mind with delusion as “mind with delusion”,
translation_text.mn73:21.8: and mind without delusion as “mind without delusion”;
translation_text.mn73:21.13: mind that is not supreme as “mind that is not supreme”,
translation_text.mn73:21.14: and mind that is supreme as “mind that is supreme”;
translation_text.mn73:21.15: mind immersed in samādhi as “mind immersed in samādhi”,
translation_text.mn73:21.16: and mind not immersed in samādhi as “mind not immersed in samādhi”;
translation_text.mn73:22.1: As far as you want, you will be capable of realizing these things, since each and every one is within range:
translation_text.mn73:22.2: ‘May I recollect many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. May I remember: “There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.” May I recollect my many past lives, with features and details.’
translation_text.mn73:23.1: Whenever you want, you will be capable of realizing these things, since each and every one is within range:
translation_text.mn73:23.2: ‘With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, may I see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place—and understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds: “These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.” And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, may I see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. And may I understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.’
translation_text.mn73:24.1: As far as you want, you will be capable of realizing these things, since each and every one is within range:
translation_text.mn73:24.2: ‘May I realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.’”
translation_text.mn73:25.1: And then Venerable Vacchagotta approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
translation_text.mn73:26.1: Then Vacchagotta, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.mn73:26.2: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”
translation_text.mn73:26.3: And Venerable Vacchagotta became one of the perfected.
translation_text.mn73:27.1: Now at that time several mendicants were going to see the Buddha.
translation_text.mn73:27.2: Vacchagotta saw them coming off in the distance,
translation_text.mn73:27.3: went up to them, and said,
translation_text.mn73:27.5: “Reverend, we are going to see the Buddha.”
translation_text.mn73:27.6: “Well then, reverends, in my name please bow with your head at the Buddha’s feet and say:
translation_text.mn73:27.7: ‘Sir, the mendicant Vacchagotta bows with his head to your feet and says,
translation_text.mn73:27.8: “I have served the Blessed One! I have served the Holy One!”’”
translation_text.mn73:28.2: Then those mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
translation_text.mn73:28.3: “Sir, the mendicant Vacchagotta bows with his head to your feet and says:
translation_text.mn73:28.4: ‘I have served the Blessed One! I have served the Holy One!’”
translation_text.mn73:28.5: “I’ve already encompassed Vacchagotta’s mind and understood that
translation_text.mn73:28.6: he has the three knowledges, and is very mighty and powerful.
translation_text.mn73:28.7: And deities also told me about this.”
translation_text.mn73:28.9: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn73:28.10: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

variant_text.mn73:7.2: sāvako yo āsavānaṁ khayā → sāvako āsavānaṁ khayā (bj, sya-all, km, pts1ed)
variant_text.mn73:17.3: uttari ca me → uttariṁ me (bj, sya-all, km, pts1ed)
